comments.content: "Some features only roll out on a per-organization basis. This means that the entire organization will receive access to the feature at the same time. For features like this, it’s not possible for selected users in the targeted release program to get the feature early. This means that your organization will not be able to receive these features early if you have configured selected users in targeted release. To make sure that you see all features in targeted release, you will need to configure targeted release for the entire organization or set up a test organization."

To enable targeted release for all users in your organization, select Targeted release for everyone, then select Save changes.
To enable targeted release for some people in your organization, select Targeted release for selected users, then select Save changes.
Choose Select users to add users one at a time, or Upload users to add them in bulk.
When you're done adding users, select Save changes.

HOTSPOT -
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.

Hot Area:
//IMG//

You have been tasked with configuring a data governance strategy that allows for data classification. It should also allow for these classifications to be enforced.
Which of the following should form part of your strategy? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
The question has two requirements, "allows for data classification," and, "allow for these classifications to be enforced." There is no requirement for data retention. "Publish Labels" allows for data classification, and "Apply Supervision Policies" allows for the enforcement of corporate policies, risk management, and regulator compliance.
https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/security-compliance-and-identity/use-supervision-to-monitor-email-microsoft-teams-manage-risk/ba-p/325827

Selected Answer: BE
I think anser is
B. Publish labels.
E. Apply retention policies.

Selected Answer: BD
B. Publish lables is straight forward.
D. Apply Supervision Policies and not Retention policies because the latter deals with how long data is retained

Selected Answer: BE
The correct answers are:

B. Publish labels
E. Apply retention policies

Explanation:
To configure a data governance strategy that allows for data classification and enforcement, the following components are essential:

B. Publish labels:
Labels in Microsoft 365 (part of Microsoft Information Protection) are used to classify data based on its sensitivity or importance. Publishing labels makes them available to users and services across the organization, enabling consistent classification of data.

E. Apply retention policies:
Retention policies ensure that data is retained or deleted according to organizational or regulatory requirements. They enforce the governance of data based on its classification and lifecycle.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/retention-policies

Selected Answer: BE
B. Publish labels: Sensitivity labels (part of Microsoft Purview) are used to classify data (e.g., "Confidential" or "Public"). Publishing labels makes them available to users/apps for classification.

E. Apply retention policies: Retention policies enforce rules based on classifications (e.g., retain data for 7 years, auto-delete after expiration). They ensure compliance with governance requirements tied to labels.
supervision policies monitor communications

B-to classify data

comments.content: That would be correct if it didn't say It should also allow for these classifications to be enforced. B,D is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Supervision policies deals with monitoring and reviewing COMMUNICATIONS within an organization to ensure compliance with legal, regulatory, or internal standards. They are applied to specific communication types (e.g., email, Teams chat, etc.) to flag content for review. They’re mostly used for monitoring content for inappropriate behavior, such as harassment, or to ensure employees follow certain communication rules. 

It has nothing to do with the enforcement of data classification!

Enforcing data classification in 365 involves using a combination of labels, retention policies, and other compliance features to ensure that data is properly classified, protected, and managed according to the organization's governance needs. Publishing labels and applying retention policies are key components that allow classification to be applied and then managed according to regulatory requirements.

B and E is the answer

I think its

Selected Answer: BE
Publish labels: Labels allow you to classify and protect data across your organization. You can apply labels to content manually or automatically based on certain conditions.

Apply retention policies: Retention policies help ensure that information is kept for a required period or deleted after a certain period, aligning with your organization's data governance strategy and compliance requirements.

Therefore, the correct answers are:
B. Publish labels
E. Apply retention policies
Publish labels.. Apply supervision policies

B. Publish labels: Use Microsoft Information Protection labels to classify and protect data consistently across your organization.
E. Apply retention policies: Implement retention policies to manage the lifecycle of data, ensuring it's retained or deleted based on your organization's policies and compliance requirements.

Correct Answer: BD

If you don’t properly label data as sensitive, you’ll be unable to locate, identify, or successfully govern it. 
Organizations need to be able to prove to auditors and regulators that privacy policies are being followed and enforced within the company.

See Also: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2022/03/31/3-strategies-to-launch-an-effective-data-governance-plan/

Publicar rótulos: Os rótulos são uma maneira de classificar os dados com base em sua sensibilidade e importância. Eles podem ser usados para identificar dados confidenciais e aplicar políticas de proteção de dados apropriadas. Os rótulos podem ser publicados em toda a organização para garantir que todos os usuários estejam cientes das políticas de classificação de dados 1. Aplicar políticas de supervisão: As políticas de supervisão permitem que você monitore o uso dos dados em sua organização e identifique possíveis violações de segurança. Você pode criar políticas para monitorar o uso de dados confidenciais, como informações financeiras ou informações pessoais identificáveis (PII), e receber alertas quando ocorrerem violações 1.

Selected Answer: BE
B. Publish labels - Labels are a key part of data classification. They allow you to categorize data based on its business context, making it easier to understand, search, and govern. You can also use labels to implement measures to protect sensitive or important data from unauthorized access.

E. Apply retention policies - Retention policies are an important part of data governance. They specify how data should be governed for each type of data classification and lifecycle management. These policies can help enforce data quality, data access security, data privacy, and lifecycle management across the distributed data landscape.

Selected Answer: BE
The answer is B and E.

D: Apply Supervision Policies

I'm not sure about this one. It's definitely not A or C for obvious reasons. B is required for the first portion. But the second portion regarding "classifications to be enforced" is the confusing part.

Retention doesn't really have anything to do with enforcing classifications. That will prevent data from being deleted
Supervision policy will monitor email, Teams, etc but that has been replaced by communication compliance
Preservation policy is a setting in retention policy and labels that blocks admins from making changes to the policy -- I'm thinking this might be the best answer

correcta ByD
https://www.recordpoint.com/advanced-data-governance-labels/

Selected Answer: BE
The other options mentioned are not directly related to data classification and enforcement:

A. Applying Microsoft SharePoint permissions is related to access control and permissions management but not specifically data classification.
C. Configuring Microsoft Outlook Mail Tips provides users with helpful tips and warnings when composing emails, but it does not pertain to data classification.
D. Applying supervision policies is relevant for monitoring and compliance purposes, but it does not specifically address data classification.
F. Applying preservation policies is related to legal holds and protecting data from alteration or deletion, but it does not focus on data classification.

[March 31 2023] The supervision solution in Office 365 has been fully replaced by the communication compliance solution in Microsoft Purview. We recommend creating new policies in communication compliance that have the same settings as existing supervision policies to use the new investigation and remediation improvements.

Selected Answer: BE
B. Publish labels: This involves creating and publishing data classification labels that can be applied to content in Microsoft 365 services such as SharePoint, OneDrive, and Exchange Online. These labels can be used to indicate the level of sensitivity of the content, and they can be used to trigger certain actions, such as applying encryption or preventing the content from being shared outside the organization.

E. Apply retention policies: This involves creating and applying retention policies to content in Microsoft 365 services such as SharePoint, OneDrive, and Exchange Online. Retention policies can be used to specify how long content should be retained, and they can also be used to trigger certain actions, such as moving content to an archive or deleting content that is no longer needed.

Therefore, options B and E should form part of the data governance strategy for data classification and enforcement.

Selected Answer: BE
Publishing labels to clearly communicate the type of data and level of protection required, and applying retention policies to manage the lifecycle of data including when to delete or archive it, should be part of the data governance strategy, as it promotes awareness, accountability and reduces risk of data breaches while adhering to regulatory requirements.
A&E, according to https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/data-classification-overview?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: AE
Publishing labels is a way of classifying data by tagging it with a label, but it does not enforce any data classification. It simply allows users to easily identify and understand the classification level of the data, but it does not restrict access to or control the retention of the data based on the classification level. While labels can be a useful tool for classifying data, they alone are not sufficient for enforcing data classification in a data governance strategy.

To enforce data classification, you need to have mechanisms in place to control access to and retention of data based on the classification level. This is where options A and E (Applying SharePoint permissions and retention policies) come in. SharePoint permissions allow you to restrict access to sensitive data to only authorized users, and retention policies allow you to ensure that data is retained for the appropriate amount of time based on its classification level and legal or regulatory requirements. Together they enforce the data classification and provide a more robust data governance strategy. Am i right?

B and E 
Retention labels help you retain what you need and delete what you don't at the item level (document or email). They are also used to declare an item as a record as part of a records management solution for your Microsoft 365 data.

Making retention labels available to people in your organization so that they can classify content is a two-step process:

Create the retention labels.

Publish the retention labels by using a retention label policy.
Classification is different to Retention. Both types need to be published but the other options don't make any sense.

A label policy consists of:

A set of labels.
The users and groups that will be assigned the policy with labels.
The scope of the policy and policy settings for that scope (such as default label for files and emails).

questions.question_text:
A company experiences a Microsoft 365 outage that affects an entire region.
You check the Service Health Dashboard and observe that the service is healthy.
After the incident is resolved, you need to find information in Service Health Dashboard that describes what happened during the outage.
What should you use?

discussion.content:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/office-365-platform-service-description/service-health-and-continuity:
"For unplanned customer-impacting service incidents in which there was broad and noticeable impact across a large number of organizations, a preliminary Post-Incident Review (PIR) will be delivered via your Service Health Dashboard within 48 hours of incident resolution, followed by a final PIR within five business days"

Answer is C

comments.content:
Correct and its worth adding that the PIR is for 'unplanned customer-impacting' service incidents

For all other service incidents, the Service health page on Microsoft 365 admin center will provide an "incident closure summary" including a final summary of the event, root cause, start and end times, and information detailing next steps. For this category of service incident, a PIR won't be generated.

discussion.content: correct
